title: Signal Report — Holiday flagship timing and event tests
highlights: Test moving a protected set of new/limited SKUs to the two weeks before Thanksgiving (6–8 week A/B test).
Use a limited-hours, parade‑weekend flagship drop to measure footfall, conversion and AOV versus a prior-weekend baseline.
Pilot AI-driven allocation/pricing in a subset of stores to target markdowns and measure margin preservation and sell‑through.
executive_summary: Holiday demand is shifting earlier; design a timing test to detect a 10–15% lift in incremental sales for a protected set of SKUs moved into the two weeks before Thanksgiving and measure margin and cannibalization to confirm net gain [^4][^3]. A flagship, parade‑weekend product drop should be instrumented to detect an 8–12% uplift in foot traffic versus baseline weekend levels and to track conversion and average order value for profitability [^1][^5]. Early-offer share is already growing—design studies to detect a 10–20% increase in early-deal share versus last year and segment by category to identify displacement in high-ticket items [^3][^4]. In the next 30 days merchandising, store operations, and analytics must lock SKU holds and holdout design, enable traffic and POS instrumentation, and agree on reporting windows so pilots can begin on schedule.
top_operator_moves: Start a 6–8 week A/B timing test for protected SKUs with randomized holdouts and margin/sell‑through tracking.
Schedule a parade‑weekend, flagship-only product drop and instrument stores for foot traffic, conversion and AOV.
Launch an 8-week AI allocation/pricing pilot in a representative store subset to compare targeted markdowns vs blanket discounts.
